column2: Jack's fame had now spread through the whole country, and at the King's desire the duke gave him his daughter in marriage, to the joy of all his kingdom.
column3: Jack's fame had now spread through the whole country, and at the King's desire the duke gave him his daughter in marriage, to the joy of all his kingdom.

column2: After this the King gave him a large estate, on which he and his lady lived the rest of their days in joy and contentment.(1)
column3: After this the King gave him a large estate, on which he and his lady lived the rest of their days in joy and contentment.(one)

column2: (1) Old Chapbook.
column3: (one) Old Chapbook.

column2: THE BLACK BULL OF NORROWAY
column3: THE BLACK BULL OF n o r r o w a y

column2: And many a hunting song they sung, And song of game and glee; Then tuned to plaintive strains their tongue, "Of Scotland's luve and lee." To wilder measures next they turn "The Black, Black Bull of Norroway!" Sudden the tapers cease to burn, The minstrels cease to play.
column3: And many a hunting song they sung, And song of game and glee; Then tuned to plaintive strains their tongue, "Of Scotland's luve and lee." To wilder measures next they turn "The Black, Black Bull of Norroway!" Sudden the tapers cease to burn, The minstrels cease to play.

column2: The Cout of Keeldar, by J. Leyden.
column3: The Cout of Keeldar, by j Leyden.

column2: In Norroway, langsyne, there lived a certain lady, and she had three dochters.
column3: In Norroway, langsyne, there lived a certain lady, and she had three dochters.

column2: The auldest o' them said to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, for I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and the dochter gaed awa' to an auld witch washerwife and telled her purpose.
column3: The auldest o' them said to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, for I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and the dochter g a e d awa' to an auld witch washerwife and telled her purpose.

column2: The auld wife bade her stay that day, and gang and look out o' her back door, and see what she could see.
column3: The auld wife bade her stay that day, and gang and look out o' her back door, and see what she could see.

column2: She saw nocht the first day.
column3: She saw nocht the first day.

column2: The second day she did the same, and saw nocht. On the third day she looked again, and saw a coach-and-six coming along the road.
column3: The second day she did the same, and saw nocht. On the third day she looked again, and saw a coach and six coming along the road.

column2: She ran in and telled the auld wife what she saw.
column3: She ran in and telled the auld wife what she saw.

column2: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." Sae they took her into the coach, and galloped aff.
column3: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." Sae they took her into the coach, and galloped a f f.

column2: The second dochter next says to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, fur I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and awa' she gaed to the auld wife, as her sister had dune.
column3: The second dochter next says to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, fur I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and awa' she g a e d to the auld wife, as her sister had dune.

column2: On the third day she looked out o' the back door, and saw a coach-and-four coming along the road.
column3: On the third day she looked out o' the back door, and saw a coach and four coming along the road.

column2: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." Sae they took her in, and aff they set.
column3: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." Sae they took her in, and a f f they set.

column2: The third dochter says to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, for I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and awa' she gaed to the auld witch-wife.
column3: The third dochter says to her mither: "Mither, bake me a bannock, and roast me a collop, for I'm gaun awa' to seek my fortune." Her mither did sae; and awa' she g a e d to the auld witch wife.

column2: She bade her look out o' her back door, and see what she could see.
column3: She bade her look out o' her back door, and see what she could see.

column2: She did sae; and when she came back said she saw nocht.
column3: She did sae; and when she came back said she saw nocht.

column2: The second day she did the same, and saw nocht.
column3: The second day she did the same, and saw nocht.

column2: The third day she looked again, and on coming back said to the auld wife she saw nocht but a muckle Black Bull coming roaring alang the road.
column3: The third day she looked again, and on coming back said to the auld wife she saw nocht but a muckle Black Bull coming roaring alang the road.

column2: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." On hearing this she was next to distracted wi' grief and terror; but she was lifted up and set on his back, and awa' they went.
column3: Aweel, quo' the auld wife, "yon's for you." On hearing this she was next to distracted wi' grief and terror; but she was lifted up and set on his back, and awa' they went.

column2: Aye they traveled, and on they traveled, till the lady grew faint wi' hunger.
column3: Aye they traveled, and on they traveled, till the lady grew faint wi' hunger.

column2: Eat out o' my right lug, says the Black Bull, "and drink out o' my left lug, and set by your leavings." Sae she did as he said, and was wonderfully refreshed.
column3: Eat out o' my right lug, says the Black Bull, "and drink out o' my left lug, and set by your leavings." Sae she did as he said, and was wonderfully refreshed.

column2: And lang they gaed, and sair they rade, till they came in sight o' a very big and bonny castle.
column3: And lang they g a e d, and sair they rade, till they came in sight o' a very big and bonny castle.

column2: Yonder we maun be this night, quo' the bull; "for my auld brither lives yonder"; and presently they were at the place.
column3: Yonder we maun be this night, quo' the bull; "for my auld brither lives yonder"; and presently they were at the place.

column2: They lifted her aff his back, and took her in, and sent him away to a park for the night.
column3: They lifted her a f f his back, and took her in, and sent him away to a park for the night.

column2: In the morning, when they brought the bull hame, they took the lady into a fine shining parlor, and gave her a beautiful apple, telling her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait ever mortal was in in the world, and that wad bring her o't.
column3: In the morning, when they brought the bull hame, they took the lady into a fine shining parlor, and gave her a beautiful apple, telling her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait ever mortal was in in the world, and that wad bring her o't.

column2: Again she was lifted on the bull's back, and after she had ridden far, and farer than I can tell, they came in sight o' a far bonnier castle, and far farther awa' than the last.
column3: Again she was lifted on the bull's back, and after she had ridden far, and farer than I can tell, they came in sight o' a far bonnier castle, and far farther awa' than the last.

column2: Says the bull till her: "Yonder we maun be the night, for my second brither lives yonder"; and they were at the place directly.
column3: Says the bull till her: "Yonder we maun be the night, for my second brither lives yonder"; and they were at the place directly.

column2: They lifted her down and took her in, and sent the bull to the field for the night.
column3: They lifted her down and took her in, and sent the bull to the field for the night.

column2: In the morning they took the lady into a fine and rich room, and gave her the finest pear she had ever seen, bidding her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait ever mortal could be in, and that wad get her out o't.
column3: In the morning they took the lady into a fine and rich room, and gave her the finest pear she had ever seen, bidding her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait ever mortal could be in, and that wad get her out o't.

column2: Again she was lifted and set on his back, and awa' they went.
column3: Again she was lifted and set on his back, and awa' they went.

column2: And lang they gaed, and sair they rade, till they came in sight o' the far biggest castle, and far farthest aff, they had yet seen.
column3: And lang they g a e d, and sair they rade, till they came in sight o' the far biggest castle, and far farthest a f f, they had yet seen.

column2: We maun be yonder the night, says the bull, "for my young brither lives yonder"; and they were there directly.
column3: We maun be yonder the night, says the bull, "for my young brither lives yonder"; and they were there directly.

column2: They lifted her down, took her in, and sent the bull to the field for the night.
column3: They lifted her down, took her in, and sent the bull to the field for the night.

column2: In the morning they took her into a room, the finest of a', and gied her a plum, telling her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait mortal could be in, and that wad get her out o't.
column3: In the morning they took her into a room, the finest of a', and g i e d her a plum, telling her no to break it till she was in the greatest strait mortal could be in, and that wad get her out o't.

column2: Presently they brought hame the bull, set the lady on his back, and awa' they went.
column3: Presently they brought hame the bull, set the lady on his back, and awa' they went.

column2: And aye they gaed, and on they rade, till they came to a dark and ugsome glen, where they stopped, and the lady lighted down.
column3: And aye they g a e d, and on they rade, till they came to a dark and ugsome glen, where they stopped, and the lady lighted down.

column2: Says the bull to her: "Here ye maun stay till I gang and fight the deil.
column3: Says the bull to her: "Here ye maun stay till I gang and fight the deil.

column2: Ye maun seat yoursel' on that stane, and move neither hand nor fit till I come back, else I'll never find ye again.
column3: Ye maun seat yoursel' on that stane, and move neither hand nor fit till I come back, else I'll never find ye again.

column2: And if everything round about ye turns blue I hae beated the deil; but should a' things turn red he'll hae conquered me." She set hersel' down on the stane, and by-and-by a' round her turned blue.
column3: And if everything round about ye turns blue I hae beated the deil; but should a' things turn red he'll hae conquered me." She set hersel' down on the stane, and by and by a' round her turned blue.

column2: O'ercome wi' joy, she lifted the ae fit and crossed it owre the ither, sae glad was she that her companion was victorious.
column3: O'ercome wi' joy, she lifted the ae fit and crossed it owre the ither, sae glad was she that her companion was victorious.

column2: The bull returned and sought for but never could find her.
column3: The bull returned and sought for but never could find her.

column2: Lang she sat, and aye she grat, till she wearied.
column3: Lang she sat, and aye she grat, till she wearied.

column2: At last she rase and gaed awa', she kedna whaur till.
column3: At last she rase and g a e d awa', she kedna whaur till.

column2: On she wandered till she came to a great hill o' glass, that she tried a' she could to climb, bat wasna able.
column3: On she wandered till she came to a great hill o' glass, that she tried a' she could to climb, bat wasna able.

column2: Round the bottom o' the hill she gaed, sabbing and seeking a passage owre, till at last she came to a smith's house; and the smith promised, if she wad serve him seven years, he wad make her iron shoon, wherewi' she could climb owre the glassy hill.
column3: Round the bottom o' the hill she g a e d, sabbing and seeking a passage owre, till at last she came to a smith's house; and the smith promised, if she wad serve him seven years, he wad make her iron shoon, wherewi' she could climb owre the glassy hill.

column2: At seven years' end she got her iron shoon, clamb the glassy hill, and chanced to come to the auld washerwife's habitation.
column3: At seven years' end she got her iron shoon, clamb the glassy hill, and chanced to come to the auld washerwife's habitation.

column2: There she was telled of a gallant young knight that had given in some bluidy sarks to wash, and whaever washed thae sarks was to be his wife.
column3: There she was telled of a gallant young knight that had given in some bluidy sarks to wash, and whaever washed thae sarks was to be his wife.

column2: The auld wife had washed till she was tired, and then she set to her dochter, and baith washed, and they washed, and they better washed, in hopes of getting the young knight; but a' they could do they couldna bring out a stain.
column3: The auld wife had washed till she was tired, and then she set to her dochter, and baith washed, and they washed, and they better washed, in hopes of getting the young knight; but a' they could do they couldna bring out a stain.

column2: At length they set the stranger damosel to wark; and whenever she began the stains came out pure and clean, but the auld wife made the knight believe it was her dochter had washed the sarks.
column3: At length they set the stranger damosel to wark; and whenever she began the stains came out pure and clean, but the auld wife made the knight believe it was her dochter had washed the sarks.

column2: So the knight and the eldest dochter were to be married, and the stranger damosel was distracted at the thought of it, for she was deeply in love wi' him.
column3: So the knight and the eldest dochter were to be married, and the stranger damosel was distracted at the thought of it, for she was deeply in love wi' him.

column2: So she bethought her of her apple, and breaking it, found it filled with gold and precious jewelry, the richest she had ever seen.
column3: So she bethought her of her apple, and breaking it, found it filled with gold and precious jewelry, the richest she had ever seen.

column2: All these, she said to the eldest dochter, "I will give you, on condition that you put off your marriage for ae day, and allow me to go into his room alone at night." So the lady consented; but meanwhile the auld wife had prepared a sleeping-drink, and given it to the knight, wha drank it, and never wakened till next morning.
column3: All these, she said to the eldest dochter, "I will give you, on condition that you put off your marriage for ae day, and allow me to go into his room alone at night." So the lady consented; but meanwhile the auld wife had prepared a sleeping drink, and given it to the knight, wha drank it, and never wakened till next morning.

column2: The lee-lang night ther damosel sabbed and sang:
column3: The lee lang night ther damosel sabbed and sang:

column2: Seven lang years I served for thee, The glassy hill I clamb for thee, The bluidy shirt I wrang for thee; And wilt thou no wauken and turn to me?
column3: Seven lang years I served for thee, The glassy hill I clamb for thee, The bluidy shirt I wrang for thee; And wilt thou no wauken and turn to me?

column2: Next day she kentna what to do for grief.
column3: Next day she kentna what to do for grief.

column2: She then brak the pear, and found it filled wi' jewelry far richer than the contents o' the apple. Wi' thae jewels she bargained for permission to be a second night in the young knight's chamber; but the auld wife gied him anither sleeping-drink, and he again sleepit till morning.
column3: She then brak the pear, and found it filled wi' jewelry far richer than the contents o' the apple. Wi' thae jewels she bargained for permission to be a second night in the young knight's chamber; but the auld wife g i e d him anither sleeping drink, and he again sleepit till morning.

column2: A' night she kept sighing and singing as before:
column3: A' night she kept sighing and singing as before:

column2: Seven lang years I served for thee, &c.
column3: Seven lang years I served for thee, and c.

column2: Still he sleepit, and she nearly lost hope a'thegither.
column3: Still he sleepit, and she nearly lost hope a'thegither.

column2: But that day when he was out at the hunting, somebody asked him what noise and moaning was yon they heard all last night in his bedchamber.
column3: But that day when he was out at the hunting, somebody asked him what noise and moaning was yon they heard all last night in his bedchamber.

column2: He said he heardna ony noise.
column3: He said he heardna ony noise.

column2: But they assured him there was sae; and he resolved to keep waking that night to try what he could hear.
column3: But they assured him there was sae; and he resolved to keep waking that night to try what he could hear.

column2: That being the third night, and the damosel being between hope and despair, she brak her plum, and it held far the richest jewelry of the three.
column3: That being the third night, and the damosel being between hope and despair, she brak her plum, and it held far the richest jewelry of the three.

column2: She bargained as before; and the auld wife, as before, took in the sleeping-drink to the young knight's chamber; but he telled her he couldna drink it that night without sweetening.
column3: She bargained as before; and the auld wife, as before, took in the sleeping drink to the young knight's chamber; but he telled her he couldna drink it that night without sweetening.

column2: And when she gaed awa' for some honey to sweeten it wi', he poured out the drink, and sae made the auld wife think he had drunk it. They a' went to bed again, and the damosel began, as before, singing:
column3: And when she g a e d awa' for some honey to sweeten it wi', he poured out the drink, and sae made the auld wife think he had drunk it. They a' went to bed again, and the damosel began, as before, singing:

column2: Seven lang years I served for thee, The glassy hill I clamb for thee, The bluidy shirt I wrang for thee; And wilt thou no wauken and turn to me?
column3: Seven lang years I served for thee, The glassy hill I clamb for thee, The bluidy shirt I wrang for thee; And wilt thou no wauken and turn to me?

column2: He heard, and turned to her.
column3: He heard, and turned to her.

column2: And she telled him a' that had befa'en her, and he telled her a' that had happened to him.
column3: And she telled him a' that had befa'en her, and he telled her a' that had happened to him.

column2: And he caused the auld washerwife and her dochter to be burned.
column3: And he caused the auld washerwife and her dochter to be burned.

column2: And they were married, and he and she are living happy till this day, for aught I ken.(1)
column3: And they were married, and he and she are living happy till this day, for aught I ken.(one)
